Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Basic microeconomics and mainly how to approach different types of economic problems.
Theory of supply and demand, equilibrium, decisions made under certainty and risk.
Some added insight to the topics discussed in intro micro, with some additional math topics added in.

This course was quite similar to Introductory Microeconomics, and so many of the skills I developed I had already built in that previous course. There's much more mathematics involved in this course, so I think I mainly improved my ability to analyze economic policies and impacts in a quantitative sense.
Strong theoretical understanding of and mathematical approaches to basic microeconomic concepts
Intermediate Microeconomics
Solid foundation in microeconomic theory.

I developed an understanding of microeconomic theory, especially as it relates to consumer theory, producer theory, perfect competition, utility, decisions under risk, game theory, and imperfect competition. I learned how to utilize multivariable calculus within economics, and also was introduced to many interesting theorems and axioms relating to economics as a whole.
Micro at a slightly deeper level than intro, although not much
a wide variety of topics in microeconomics
I got better at algebra. I remembered the quadratic equation.

This course gave me a much better understanding of microeconomics and consumer theory, among other things. Professor Borgers really focused on understanding the concepts and not just regurgitating formulas, which I really appreciated.
More advanced skills in microeconomics
I really dont think I learned anything in this course that I will be helpful. Maybe game theory.
I learned how to optimize the most fundamental problems in microeconomics, our them together in equilibrium, and critically evaluate a few tools for assessing welfare.

I learned the theory of intermediate microeconomics, with specific attention to consumer and producer habits. I also learned quantitative skills regarding the maximization of utility, description of preferences, and prediction of equilibrium behaviors that result in a market.
I learnt some basic models in microeconomics which helps me to decide if I want to major in Econ.
The course gave good, thorough review of microeconomic concepts.  Many were similar to the introductory micro class.
I gained a deeper understanding on microeconomics, primarily from a mathematical standpoint.
You learn similar things to microeconomics (consumer theory, theory of the firm, perfect competition, etc.) With a bit more math. A few new concepts such as welfare theorems also come up.
I learned a lot about markets and concepts behind consumer spending which was really cool!
I learned about the mathematics-based side of microeconomics and how every aspect of microeconomics is actually all intertwined.
I developed the ability to further analyze and solve microeconomic concepts and problems.
micro
Formulation of microeconomic models and analysis of consumer and first behaviour and there interaction in the markets at large.
I learned a lot of economic intuition
A good understanding of the theory behind microeconomics, and factors that come into play when making decisions in everything from welfare policy to auctions. Quite fun!

This course was a helpful extension of many of the concepts covered in Intro Micro, with the addition of a few new topics such as lotteries and auctions. I would say the primary skill developed was the ability to interpret economic intuitions in a more formal and mathematical way.
I learned a lot about how to mathematically model economic concepts that I was already somewhat familiar with, but this class made me understand what goes on behind the scenes.
Professor did a fantastic job applying real world concepts to the calculations we were studying.
A little bit about intermediate microeconomic theory. A bit about the methods used by economists.
Good understanding of Micro and Game Theory, conceptual and quantitative.
This course was more similar to introductory microeconomics than I was expecting. Some of the math was more difficult, but the concepts were mostly the same.

Through taking this course, I learned how theoretical and technical economics can be. In high school, economics seemed very concrete and straight forward. This class taught me that economics involves many assumptions and conditions, and is often not definite. This class also showed me that economics involves applications of calculus, which increased my interest in the subject.
Skills to push my microeconomics forward -- Hicksian demand, LaGrangians, etc.

I feel like I learned a greater knowledge of the generalized side of what I learned in intro micro. We spent a lot more time on finding generalized equations for things and a lot less time on things like imperfect competition markets. I also got a glimpse into game theory, although I will need to take game theory in the future.

I developed knowledge about various functions needed to calculate demand, production, and equilibrium all from a few variables. There was a lot of equation and variable manipulation involved for this course, and definitely more detailed than the concepts in intro micro.
I learned to incorporate multivariable calculus into economics and to evaluate the consequences of public policy on general equilibrium.
Mainly optimization skills, ways to maximize utility/production functions, the concept of welfare and if that is even a valid question or not, game theory
Intermediate Microeconomics analysis
I learned about microeconomics in more detail along with different approaches.
Learned a deeper, mathematics-based side of microeconomics.
Covers the topics of Intro Micro, but with more math - which I thought made it better and more understandable than intro.

We did not have enough time to finish the material and despite the fact that the professor decided to omit the last lecture, I still felt that the last few lectures were rushed in their explanations and examples. 
My suggestion for improvement is increased efficacy. We could have moved the material more quickly if we have omitted the long pauses and summaries in between examples presented in class.

The strength of this course was absolutely Professor Borgers. I wish we was staying at Yale and could teach this class to future generations. Borges truly cared about his students engagement and learning, providing helpful lecture notes and practice problems.

This class didn't seem to add that much over intro micro; in effect it was a slightly more mathematical approach to many of the exact some idea. The Prof wasn't overly into using complex math, which made the class easier, but also meant that it was really almost the same as intro.

Strengths: Tilman's lectures; notes and additional problems posted online
Weaknesses: no major complaints

Strengths: clear lecture notes

Weaknesses: difficulty of exams not proportional to difficulty of problem sets / exercises discussed in class
The syllabus is well-organized, even though we didn't manage to finish everything

The strengths of this course are the very clearly written lecture notes which allow students to get a better understanding of the concepts that were learned in lecture. Additionally, some of the teaching assistants are very helpful when it comes to understanding the course content. The weaknesses of this course are the fact that the problem sets can be very difficult. Furthermore, sometimes lectures were unhelpful as we did not finish the content of a particular topic and had to move on from that topic, but were still expected to know the material. Exams were very difficult as a whole, particularly the midterms.
Very standard core econ class. Interesting material to a point, hard to stay engaged in a 200-person lecture.
lectures could be dry. game theory was hard for me to understand and the professor kind of flew through the material.
The course was very well taught. Professor Borgers not only put up slides and practice problems every week, but he also put up lecture notes and was always available to answer any questions.

It is honestly not a very engaging course and is very difficult; I am not sure how it could be improved, however, and most of my lack of engagement came from personal issues I was dealing with throughout the semester that made it difficult to focus

This course I a painful experience but unfortunately required for the Econ major. He lecture notes were very helpful but a weakness would be that lecture was almost counterproductive. It was better to read the notes on your own. I wish the course had a piazza page for questions because it was difficult to get help.

The course gives you the fundamental building blocks of microeconomics. I also think Professor Borgers did a great job giving us the tools to assess notions of welfare, and to critically analyze what we were doing.
The lecture slides were not very word-intensive, which made it difficult to review for the exams. Professor Borgers was a great lecturer, but at times the lessons were difficult to follow.
The lecture notes and slides are helpful while reviewing this class.

The strength is that the slides and lecture notes are very thorough and the classes are entertaining.  The weakness is that there is no textbook with Prof. Borgers, so there is only one type of explanation given for each concept.

Strengths: a lot of great resources (lecture slides/notes, practice problems, etc.) and generally the topics were pretty clear

Weaknesses: I disliked how it walked the line between Mathematically rigorous and basic. Dont half-way explain the proof, either do it or dont. I also thought that class moved super slowly  we didnt cover everything we were supposed to.

Strengths: Pretty straight forward, TFs and the Professor were great.

Weakness: Worried that it might not be on par in terms of mathematical rigor than previous intermediate Micro courses.
The classes run well and the professor was great but the tests had a lot of material that you had to come up with during the exam which was hard

The course material was organized well into related topics. I appreciated the fact that there was no textbook for this course; reading the textbook would have been another added hassle, and it would not have explained the material as well. I also appreciated that the final exam was not cumulative. The time and location of the course could have been changed, because it detracted from some of the learning, but that could not have been changed.

My TA (Julian) was incredible in helping us solidify the concepts taught during lecture. I really benefited from the way he structured and taught his section, but I think the lecture could have been improved upon. We spent a long time talking about consumer theory, and as a result the last portion of the course felt very rushed.
disadvantages students who haven't taken multivariable calculus
Good resources and teaching.
It was extremely strong at the beginning, he was a very clear and concise teacher, but towards the end, the information was more scattered and we usually did not get to the end of the lecture slides.
Very theoretical - which is nice at some points, but can get tedious at others. It'd be nice to have more practical examples to complement the current material.

In terms of strengths, the teaching assistants were all very helpful, the lectures were well-organized, and Professor Borgers was funny and approachable. In terms of weaknesses, I think the course would benefit from more real-life applications of the theory, and I think we could see more working out of examples in the lecture.
A lot of the calculations seemed tedious, and I was sometimes frustrated with the emphasis on edge cases, but overall it really helped me develop my understanding of economics.
I found the course to be quite simple in the types of concepts it covered -- not sure if that was the general consensus, but I believe a weakness was that it was very introductory in scope.
Lecture notes provided as supplements to class were great resources but often classes felt rushed. We didn't have time to finish all of the planned material.

The lecture notes and slides were very detailed and useful, so going to class was rarely necessary. Similarly, sections were not useful at all, and I would propose more TA office hours instead of sections so they can focus on the content that students need the most help with. But overall, the Psets and exams were very fair, and I think this was a solid class given the relatively dry content.
the professor is excellent

A MAJOR strength of this course was that the lecture notes were quite clear, and the professor was very clear on what he expected us to know. A weakness of this course was that the TA, peer tutor, and professor office hours were at odd and inconvenient times (such as tuesdays at 11:45, when many students, including myself, have class).

Strengths -- very good learning materials offered by Prof Borgers. Tons of resources available to you to get better at Micro.
Weaknesses -- very large class
The strengths is that this course is very comprehensive and there are a lot of practice questions for you, but i wish the lecture were more engaging.
I wish there was more content on game theory.

Strengths: The lecture notes in this class was amazing. It had most of the ideas covered in lecture so if you missed something or didn't really understand, the lecture notes saved your life. 

Weaknesses: Content (which is dry and boring), Lecture (which wasn't that compelling), midterms (the first one was too easy and the second one was too difficult, which makes the first midterm irrelevant to your grade since the class is on a curve), and always the curve in the economics department
Well explained lectures, however, pacing could be improved as we did not cover all topics
The course was good, more practice could have been beneficial.
Professor was excellent, class was overall all really good
Love the lecture notes, extremely useful for studying.

Yes, if you have to take it for your major. That being said, Professor Borgers made it very accessible to all students. It's actually not that much work and very doable IF Professor Borgers is your teacher. IF not, good luck to you.
Yes, but only with Professor Borgers.
You probably have to take this class, but I feel like I didn't learn anything new from the course. If anything, I would take this instead of intro micro and you would probably be fine..

I think the majority of students take this course to fulfill major requirements -- and in that sense, it's a good course. The expectations are very clear, and the problem sets and practice problems are comprehensive but well-explained in section and the class. I think my economic understanding is definitely better as a result of this course.
Yes, but only with Tilman. His humor made the lectures, which otherwise contained relatively dry content, enjoyable and interesting.
No
Yes. It is useful.

I would recommend this course to another student, but with caveats. While the course did teach a lot, it was often very difficult to understand the content and required a high level of engagement going to office hours, section, and getting additional help at times  in order to succeed. Furthermore, the course content is very technical and mathematical; only near the end were we discussing theory. It was also difficult to anticipate the types of problems that would be asked on the exam, given that there was no textbook and no way to practice example problems besides the few that were posted by the professor.
You're only taking it because you have to; that said, it's pretty painless and there are some interesting spots along the way.
yes, you must take it if you even want to touch economics at Yale.
don't take this class unless you need it.
I would recommend it to those who are truly passionate and interested in pursuing a degree or career in economics.
Most people who take this course take it for their major but I would recommend it to anyone interested in microeconomics.
No, unless it is a major requirement or prerequisite for another class; it is very intensive and difficult, and I would avoid it at all costs if possible
Yes only if you have to.
Yes, not as bad as they make it or to seem if you stay diligent and pay attention in lecture.
I would recommend this course to another student because I feel like I acquired a great understanding of economic behaviors.
Yes. Its a good taste of how Econ is like as a beginner.
I would recommend taking this course because I felt like I learned a lot and the coursework was very manageable.
If you are an Econ major you have to take it. But otherwise, I doubt youll learn that much more useful stuff than in intro, so probably dont bother.
Take it if you have to or if you're really enthralled by theoretical concepts.
Yes if you want to learn about the concepts behind consumer spending but the tests are fairly difficult compared to other econ classes

I would definitely recommend this course. It provides a new insight to economics that is very different from introductory micro/macroeconomics. You really don't need any prior knowledge of economics or multivariable calculus to understand the course material, although it would be helpful.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students who have background knowledge in a college-level microeconomics course. I took this course as a first-year student and struggled to fill in the gaps that my AP courses taught me, so I wouldn't recommend it to other first years.
yes, for the major
Yes.
If it's not a requirement for your major, probably not.

I would recommend this to students who are interested in economics. It probably will not be that exciting if you do not already have some foundational interest in econ since the lectures can be dry at times, but the class was very well-taught and well-organized. Also, the workload is not very heavy with just one short pset each week, two midterms, and a noncumulative final.
Sure, it's chill.
Yes, I enjoyed the insights and applications I learned.

Unless this course is required for a major, I would say its probably not the most interesting course in the econ department. But for someone particularly interested in building a foundation in economic theory, this class does do that.
yes, professor is great

Yes, if a student is interested in economics I would recommend taking this course. Although there were times when I was overwhelmed by the sheer amount of knowledge we were expected to know, by the end of the semester I had had time to process the information and overall felt that I had learned a lot. Although it might take more work, it is definitely an enriching class.
Yes, Professor Borgers was a great professor.

It's hard to say because professor Borgers is only here for one year. I had a great time in intro micro with professor Berry and I have no idea about how this class usually goes with it's usual professor. Purely from my own experience, I'd say if you don't need to take intermediate micro, take intro with berry.
I would not recommend this course to a student that does not need to take it. It's theory-heavy, and there's not much to gain in terms of real-world applications.
Yes.

No! Do not take this course (unless absolutely necessary for major which sadly are most Yale student who have metamorphosed into finance snakes hisss.......). I made the mistake of taking this class as a "fun and different" class, and I regret it. The class isn't that difficult conceptually, but its like trying to eat 3 loaves of stale bread--easy and doable if you need to but absolutely disgusting. 

The content is somewhat of a mixed bag of different concepts in economics and tying them together is very difficult until you reach close to the end of the semester (which I feel that the big thematic idea is trying to find optimal choice and using calculus to find that). The concepts and examples are too abstract and arbitrary. Although the professor told us to review the data prior to making any judgments on the theory, these utility and production functions seemed too artificial and not applicable at all. There is little explanation why we should take these theories as models for the world, and less explanation why they prove useful in higher economics. The professor defers these questions to later economics courses, but this class makes me question whether or not I should even take those future courses. To make these worse, the material is not very inspiring, and can get really dry. A common sight (which I feel bad for the professor) are students falling asleep in class. Professor Borgers is a very smart and very kind man, and this kind of disrespect is unacceptable. However, even he could not redeem the material as it drags economics to a pseudo-science/pseudo-academic subject. The material is just not that relevant and contradictory.
Yes, required for economics major.
Yes I would recommend this course because I learned a lot and it was enjoyable, but it is intense.
If taught with this professor, which won't happen again, yes.  If not, take at your own risk.
If you're interested in it. Tip: Take it with Borgers, I hear it was more mathematically difficult before.
